Article.ArticleTitle: Ozonation of Microcystins: Kinetics and Toxicity Decrease.

AbstractText: The ozonation of six microcystins (MCs) (MC-LR, MC-RR, MC-LA, MC-LF, MC-YR, and MC-LW) was investigated with a focus on the kinetics and decrease in toxicity. Second-order rate constants for the reactions of the six MCs with O<sub>3</sub> and <sup>•</sup>OH ( k<sub>O<sub>3</sub>,MC</sub> and k<sub><sup>•</sup>OH,MC</sub>) ranged from 7.1 × 10<sup>5</sup> to 6.1 × 10<sup>6</sup> M<sup>-1</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> ( k<sub>O<sub>3</sub>,MC</sub>) and from 1.2 × 10<sup>10</sup> to 1.8 × 10<sup>10</sup> M<sup>-1</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> ( k<sub><sup>•</sup>OH,MC</sub>), at pH 7.2 and 20 °C. The activation energies were calculated to be 21.6-34.5 and 11.6-13.1 kJ mol<sup>-1</sup> for k<sub>O<sub>3</sub>,MC</sub> and k<sub><sup>•</sup>OH,MC</sub>, respectively. The rate constants did not show an important pH dependency, except for k<sub>O<sub>3</sub>,MC-YR</sub>, which increased at pH > 7. A kinetic model using the determined rate constants and the measured exposures of O<sub>3</sub> and <sup>•</sup>OH was able to precisely predict the removal of MCs in natural water. The hepatotoxicities of MCs were decreased by ozonation; the toxicities of the four MCs (MC-LR, MC-RR, MC-LA, and MC-LF) decreased nearly concurrently with decreases in their concentrations. However, MC-YR and MC-LW showed a gap between the concentration and toxicity as a result of the incomplete destruction of the Adda moiety (a key amino acid expressing the hepatotoxicity of MCs). A product study using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry identified a number of oxidation products with an intact Adda moiety produced by the ozonation of MC-YR and MC-LW.
